subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: Neil, Thank you for the example. Would it be sufficient to make invokeTestMethod(Method method) protected so you could subclass TestClassRunner? private void
messageBody:
Neil,

Thank you for the example. Would it be sufficient to make
invokeTestMethod(Method method) protected so you could subclass
TestClassRunner?

private void invokeTestMethod(Method method) throws Exception {
Object test= fTestClass.getConstructor().newInstance();
new TestMethodRunner(test, method, fNotifier).run();
}

In general, I prefer to make all non-externally-visible methods protected,
since I don't know a priori which ones will prove useful as hooks for
further extension.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> Kent Beck wrote:
> > * RunWith -- class annotation directing JUnit 4 to use a
> customer runner
> > (was called Factory)
> >
> >
>
> This RunWith annotation offers an alternative to the possibility of
> decorating a test class TestSuite in JUnit3 but does not offer a
> solution to decorating the individual test methods.
>
> Lets say I code a custom Runner to run each test in it's own
> classloader
> but otherwise I want all the other standard JUnit4 annotations to be
> respected. I can reuse the TestIntrospector and
> TestMethodRunner classes
> (although they are in an internal package). But there is
> still code in
> TestClassRunner to do with exception handling that I will
> have to duplicate.
>
> - Neil
